  sgcool_label_text: Zao Wou-ki (1920 - 2013) is a Chinese-French artist who was recognised internationally as a significant figure in the modernist movement of Post-World War II. He was also regarded as a leading master in the context of the modern Asian art
 and was widely considered to be one of the most successful living Chinese artists. 3.5.62 is a good example of Zao\u0027s early abstract imagery. As shown in this example
 Zao\u0027s abstract schema is often framed within stable and simplified structures sectioned by horizontal segments. In the middle of the composition
 forces and tensions are generated by layered interweaving colours and brushstrokes
 which echo atmospheric energy and natural momentum. The imagery denotes the spiritual essence of the landscape-and-mountain painting in the tradition of Chinese art.

metadata.physical_appearance: The is an abstract painting comprising of overlapping strokes of paint. Most of the strokes are congregated in the center of the composition, where horizontal strokes break into the swirl of overlapping colours.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Zao Wou-ki (1920 - 2013) is a Chinese-French artist who was recognised internationally as a significant figure in the modernist movement of Post-World War II. He was also regarded as a leading master in the context of the modern Asian art, and was widely considered to be one of the most successful living Chinese artists. 3.5.62 is a good example of Zao's early abstract imagery. As shown in this example, Zao's abstract schema is often framed within stable and simplified structures sectioned by horizontal segments. In the middle of the composition, forces and tensions are generated by layered interweaving colours and brushstrokes, which echo atmospheric energy and natural momentum. The imagery denotes the spiritual essence of the landscape-and-mountain painting in the tradition of Chinese art.
